Award.AwardTitle: Rib kinematics and intercostal muscle function in amniotes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Breathing seems like one of the simplest things we do, but actually the structures and motions of the rib cage are enormously complex. Ribs and associated muscles (the intercostal muscles) contribute to breathing in humans and other animals, but the exact respiratory actions of the ribs and intercostal muscles have been controversial for centuries. Why is it so difficult to infer the actions of these muscles from their structure and attachments to the ribs? The answer lies in: (1) the 3D complexity of rib shape; (2) the 3D complexity of rib motion during breathing; (3) the 3D complexity of intercostal muscles; and (4) variation in all of the above from top to bottom and front to back of the rib cage. Decades of work on dogs and humans have finally yielded a solid understanding of exhalation and inhalation in these mammals, but the work has been slow and laborious. Now a new 3D X-ray technology, X-ray Reconstruction of Moving Morphology (XROMM), has just become available and will vastly speed up the collection of data on bone shape and bone motion in living animals. In this project, XROMM will be used to determine 3D rib shape, 3D rib motion, and intercostal muscle function in seven species: three lizards, two birds, an alligator, and a crocodile. These animals were selected because they show a diverse spectrum of rib shapes, rib joint morphologies, body forms, and locomotor behaviors (swimming, running and flying). The advent of XROMM will make it possible to add these seven new species to the current knowledge of just two species, all within just three years. In the future, the results of this work can be used to reconstruct the respiratory system of extinct animals, with particular relevance to the controversial respiratory mechanisms of dinosaurs.
The project includes interdisciplinary training for a Postdoctoral Fellow and a doctoral student, contributions to K-12 education, to increasing participation of underrepresented groups, and to enhancing scientific infrastructure. The postdoc and graduate student will gain interdisciplinary training through interactions with our collaborators in Engineering, Computer Science, and the Center for Computation and Visualization. The postdoc and graduate student will take the lead on specific projects, mentor undergraduate researchers, and work with K-12 teachers from the Providence Public Schools. More than 80% of students in the Providence Public School system are from underrepresented groups and more than 80% qualify for free or reduced cost lunch. In cooperation with K-12 teachers, the scientists will develop and deliver lessons and projects to teach the students about animal motion, biomechanics, and scientific methods such as XROMM. Toward enhancing scientific infrastructure, the XROMM technology will be improved and new software developed to simplify the data analysis. All hardware and software innovations are made public and are available to colleagues (through an NSF Research Coordination Network and via www.xromm.org). The complete metadata generated by the study will be published immediately through a public online database (xromm.ccv.brown.edu/webportal/). Metadata publication allows colleagues to see the contents of the data sets and suggest collaborations. After publication or after 10 years, whichever is earlier, all data will be made public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rib Kinematics and Intercostal Muscle Function in Amniotes

Intellectual Merit

Breathing seems like one of the simplest things we do, but actually the structures and motions of the rib cage are enormously complex. Ribs and associated muscles (the intercostal muscles) contribute to breathing in humans and other animals, but the exact respiratory actions of the ribs and intercostal muscles have been controversial for centuries. Why is it so difficult to infer the actions of these muscles from their structure and attachments to the ribs? The answer lies in: (1) the 3D complexity of rib shape; (2) the 3D complexity of rib motion during breathing; (3) the 3D complexity of intercostal muscles; and (4) variation in all of the above from top to bottom and front to back of the rib cage.

Now a new 3D X-ray technology, X-ray Reconstruction of Moving Morphology (XROMM), has accelerated the collection of data on bone shape and bone motion in living animals. In this project, XROMM was used to measure 3D rib shape, 3D rib motion, and intercostal muscle function in five species (all members of the group Amniota): three lizards species (green iguanas, tegus, and monitor lizards), one bird species (Turkey) and one crocodilian species (American alligators). These species were selected because they show a diverse spectrum of rib shapes, rib joint morphologies, body forms, and locomotor behaviors (swimming, running and flying). Data were collected from 3-4 individuals of each species, for a total of 17 individual animals studied.

The results from the five species were surprisingly consistent: in every case the internal intercostal muscles near the sternum (parasternal muscles) make the greatest contribution to inhalation. Even when the 3D shape and motions of the vertebral ribs are widely divergent, the morphology and motion of the sternal rib segments are conserved, as might be expected from their conserved function. We hypothesize that the conservation of form and function of these ventrally-located elements may free the dorsally-located vertebral ribs and intercostal muscles to adapt to divergent locomotor modes in these species.

The mechanism of thorax expansion, driven by the sternal ribs and parasternal internal intercostal muscles, is also conserved. In the parasternal region we have discovered an "internal crank" mechanism for rib cage expansion. The biomechanical problem is that muscle tissue only does work while shortening, not lengthening, so how can muscles act to expand the rib cage? To restate the question more specifically for ribs and intercostal muscles, how can muscle fibers that lie in the space between two ribs cause the ribs to move apart from each other? Such a mechanism would require shortening of the intercostal muscles between two ribs to cause the width of the intercostal space to increase. This seems improbable, but in fact appears to be happening in the sternal ribs and parasternal intercostal muscles in amniotes. The muscle fibers lie at a high angle to the sternal ribs in this area, and shortening causes the diagonal of a parallelogram formed by two adjacent sternal ribs to shorten, which cranks the two ribs apart.

Broader Impacts

The "internal crank" mechanism is currently being adapted for application in biomimetics and robotics. Other broader impacts of this project were: interdisciplinary research training for five undergraduates, five graduate students and one postdoc; contributions to K-12 education; contributions to increasing participation of underrepresented groups in the sciences; and to enhancing scientific infrastructure. Students and the postdoc received interdisciplinary training through interactions with our collaborators in Engineering, Computer Science, and the Center for Computation and Visualization. Members of the team contributed lessons and led an after school science club at the Paul Cuffee High school, a public charter school in Providence RI where 77% of the students qualify for free or reduced price lunch and 90% are from underrepresented groups. Toward enhancing scientific infrastructure, methods developed for this project advanced XROMM development. All hardware and software innovations are open source and have been made publicly available (via www.xromm.org). The complete metadata generated by the project have been published on the XMAPortal, an online database (xmaportal.org). All video and XROMM data from this project have been or will be made public upon publication of each sub-project in a peer-reviewed journal, or at 10 years maximum from the start of the project. The permanent ID numbers for the datasets on XMAPortal are BROWN5, BROWN10, BROWN29, BROWN42, BROWN45.
